results.title: And Now Let’s Review …
results.abstract: A.O. Scott conducts his own exit interview as he moves to a new post after more than two decades of reviewing films.

results.title: ‘Moving On’ Review: Cracking Jokes and Settling Scores
results.abstract: Lily Tomlin and Jane Fonda team up in an awkward comedy about two women contemplating the murder of a predatory man.

multimedia.caption: In “Moving On,” Lily Tomlin and Jane Fonda play Evelyn and Claire, two college pals whose paths cross at the funeral of another old friend.
In “Moving On,” Lily Tomlin and Jane Fonda play Evelyn and Claire, two college pals whose paths cross at the funeral of another old friend.

results.abstract: The problem with this sequel is that the character used up his best ideas in the first movie.

results.title: ‘Rimini’ Review: Just an Austrian Gigolo
results.abstract: The director Ulrich Seidl’s unsettling drama tracks the exploitative behaviors of an aging lounge singer, his fans and family members.

results.title: After Her Oscar Win, Will Michelle Yeoh Get to Lead Again?
results.abstract: The historic victory should mean opportunities to star again, but too often after such milestones, Hollywood doesn’t find central roles for women of color.

multimedia.caption: Michelle Yeoh with her historic trophy. She has roles lined up but no starring ones.

results.abstract: The latest film from Zhang Yimou weaves slapstick fun into an investigation of a 12th-century political murder.

results.title: Five Science Fiction Movies to Stream Now
results.abstract: In this month’s picks, a man lives life in fast-forward, teenagers die in a time loop and someone named Searcher finds a strange world.

results.title: ‘The Spirit of ’45’ Review: Here Comes Nationalization
results.abstract: A documentary from Ken Loach sees the end of World War II as a brief moment of possibility for socialism in Britain.

results.title: Adam Sandler Is Awarded the Mark Twain Prize for American Humor
results.abstract: The comedy star was celebrated at the Kennedy Center in Washington for his prolific three-decade career as an actor, writer, producer and stand-up comic.
org_facet: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts

multimedia.caption: Adam Sandler became the 24th comic to receive the Mark Twain Prize For American Humor on Sunday night.

results.title: ‘Rye Lane’ Aims to Show You a Real London Love Story
results.abstract: A rare British romantic comedy with Black leads, Raine Allen-Miller’s debut feature celebrates London neighborhoods that are changing fast.

multimedia.caption: In “Rye Lane,” David Jonsson and Vivian Oparah play heartbroken Londoners who spend a day wandering around two lively South London neighborhoods.

results.title: Review: ‘Pinball: The Man Who Saved the Game’
results.abstract: The mesmerizing silver ball, banned for decades in New York for its perils, pings from bumper to bumper in a film that tilts toward the underwhelming.

results.title: ‘The Magician’s Elephant’ Review: The Promise of a Pachyderm
results.abstract: Adapted from Kate DiCamillo’s beloved children’s book, this animated adventure sands down the somberness of its source material while turning up the silliness.

results.title: ‘Rodeo’ Review: The Good, the Bad and the Kids on Motorbikes
results.abstract: This naturalistic drama from France follows a young woman as she immerses herself in the underground world of urban motorbiking — it’s a seductive thrill-ride that falters as a character study.

results.title: ‘Wildflower’ Review: The Parents Are All Right

results.title: ‘Are You Lonesome Tonight?’ Review: Hit and Run, Sleight of Hand

results.title: When Best Picture Winners Overcome a Release Early in the Year
results.abstract: “Everything Everywhere All at Once” isn’t the first top film to have its debut long before awards season. But it is one of the few to go the distance.

results.title: ‘Lumière’: An Actress Destined to Be in the Light

results.title: A24 Achieves Art-House Supremacy With Triumphant Oscar Night
results.abstract: The independent studio behind “Everything Everywhere All at Once” and “The Whale” became the first to sweep the acting awards and win best director and best picture in the same year.
